figures.description: Production‑possibility diagram for Question 1. Horizontal axis: Goods X; vertical axis: Goods Y. A concave frontier runs from the Y‑axis intercept through points P and M to the X‑axis intercept labelled L. Point N lies inside the curve. Full‑employment/efficient points are on the curve (e.g. P and M); L on the axis and N inside are inefficient.

Marginal‑utility table for Question 2. Units of consumption of commodity X and corresponding marginal utility (MU) in 'utils': \(1 \to 100\), \(2 \to 80\), \(3 \to 50\), \(4 \to 20\). Total utility for \(n\) units is \(TU_n = \sum_{i=1}^n MU_i\).

Age‑distribution table for Questions 6 and 7. Age ranges (years) and percentage of population in 1960 and 1990: 60 and above: 35% (1960), 38% (1990); 18–59: 40%, 42%; 1–17: 25%, 20%. Dependants are 0–17 and 60+; active population is 18–59.

Short‑run cost schedule for Question 11. Columns: Total output Q (units), fixed cost FC (₦), variable cost VC (₦). Data: (100, 100, 100), (120, 100, 110), (160, 100, 120), (200, 100, 140), (240, 100, 160). Total cost is \(TC = FC + VC\); average total cost is \(ATC = TC/Q\).

Price‑control diagram for Question 13. Downward‑sloping demand curve D and upward‑sloping supply curve S intersect at equilibrium price between \(P_1\) and \(P_2\). A horizontal line at price \(P_2\) is imposed by government above equilibrium, representing a minimum (support) price.

Demand diagram for Question 14. Vertical axis: price; horizontal axis: quantity. A downward‑sloping demand curve D meets the price line \(P_1\). The triangular area between the demand curve and the horizontal price line, from Q = 0 to Q = Q\_1, is shaded as consumer surplus.

Diagram for Question 15. Original demand curve \(D_0D_0\) and original supply curve \(S_0S_0\) intersect at quantity \(Q_2\). New demand curve \(D_1D_1\) and new supply curve \(S_1S_1\) intersect at a different quantity labelled among \(Q_1, Q_2, Q_3, Q_4\). Candidates must select the new equilibrium quantity.

Cost and revenue diagram for Question 19. Vertical axis: price/cost; horizontal axis: quantity. U‑shaped average‑cost curve AC and upward‑sloping marginal‑cost curve MC. A horizontal marginal‑revenue curve MR at price P intersects MC at point L and AC at a different point. Vertical projections from O, N, K, L, F mark alternative output levels.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

questions.question: In the production‑possibility diagram for goods X and Y (figure Econ1998_PPF_FullEmployment), full employment is indicated by point
questions.explanation: Points on the PPF (P and M) represent full employment, while point N (inside the curve) and L (on an axis) indicate under‑utilization. The scan does not clearly show which of P or M the examiners designated; consult an official key.

questions.question: Using the marginal‑utility schedule in figure Econ1998_MU_Table, the total utility for an individual who consumes 3 units of commodity X is
questions.explanation: Total utility for 3 units: \(TU_3 = 100 + 80 + 50 = 230\) units.

questions.question: One of the economic problems of Nigeria today arises from

options.text: the over‑utilization of human and natural resources
the underutilization of human and natural resources

questions.explanation: Nigeria’s problem is not lack of resources but their **underutilization and misallocation**.

questions.question: In certain circumstances, a centrally planned economy adopts the rationing system because of

options.text: the scarcity of goods and services in the market
the need for equitable distribution of goods and services

questions.explanation: Rationing is typically used to **ensure fair and equitable distribution** when goods are scarce.

questions.question: Given that \(B\) = births, \(D\) = deaths, \(X\) = emigrants and \(M\) = immigrants, the population of a country over a period of time will rise if
questions.explanation: If births equal deaths (\(B-D=0\)) and **immigration exceeds emigration** (\(M > X\)), population increases.

questions.question: Using the age‑distribution table in figure Econ1998_PopAge_Table, the change in the dependency ratio between 1960 and 1990 is that it
questions.explanation: Dependants (%): 1960 = \(35 + 25 = 60\); 1990 = \(38 + 20 = 58\). Dependent share fell from 60% to 58%, i.e. **decreased by 2 percentage points**.

questions.question: From the same table (figure Econ1998_PopAge_Table), in 1990 the difference between the dependent population and the active population ratio is
questions.explanation: Dependants = \(38 + 20 = 58\)%; active = 42%. Difference = \(58 - 42 = 16\)%.

questions.question: The short‑run period in production is defined as a period when

options.text: there is at least one fixed factor
all costs of production must be covered

questions.explanation: In the **short run** at least one factor of production is fixed.

questions.question: Specialization often improves economic performance because it

options.text: permits exploitation of economies of scale
is based on the law of variable proportions
allocates resources according to absolute advantage

questions.explanation: By focusing on particular tasks, firms can produce on a larger scale and enjoy **economies of scale**.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between average product and marginal product?

options.text: Marginal product and average product curves rise and fall together
Marginal product equals average product at the minimum point of the latter
Average product curve will rise as long as marginal product is greater than average product
Marginal product equals average product at the maximum point of the former

questions.explanation: AP rises when **MP > AP**, peaks where **MP = AP**, and falls when **MP < AP**.

questions.question: Using the cost schedule in figure Econ1998_SR_Cost_Table, the average total cost when output is 200 units is
When a firm is reaping economies of large‑scale production, it experiences a fall in its
questions.explanation: Economies of scale mean **falling long‑run average cost (LRAC)** as output increases.

questions.question: In the price‑control diagram (figure Econ1998_PriceControl), the price \(P_2\) is referred to as
questions.explanation: Since \(P_2\) is set **above the equilibrium price** to support producers, it is a **minimum (floor) price**.

questions.question: In the demand diagram (figure Econ1998_ConsumerSurplus), the shaded triangle is known as
questions.explanation: Consumer surplus is the **area between the demand curve and the price line** up to the quantity purchased.

questions.question: In the multi‑shift demand–supply diagram (figure Econ1998_Shifted_Demand_Supply), \(D_0D_0\) is the original demand curve, \(S_0S_0\) the original supply curve, \(D_1D_1\) the new demand curve and \(S_1S_1\) the new supply curve. The new equilibrium quantity is
questions.explanation: The scan does not clearly show the intersection point of \(D_1D_1\) and \(S_1S_1\); please confirm the correct label with a clearer diagram or official key.

questions.question: If an increase in the price of a commodity leads to an increase in total revenue, then the demand for this commodity is
questions.explanation: With **inelastic demand** (\(|E_d| < 1\)), price and total revenue move in the same direction.

questions.question: Given that the elasticity of demand for a commodity is 2.5, the percentage change in quantity demanded as a result of a 10 per cent change in its price is
questions.explanation: Price elasticity: \(E_d = \frac{\%\Delta Q}{\%\Delta P}\). So \(\%\Delta Q = E_d \times \%\Delta P = 2.5 \times 10\% = 25\%\).

questions.question: The producer in a perfectly competitive market is faced with a demand curve whose elasticity is
questions.explanation: Each firm in perfect competition faces a **perfectly elastic (horizontal) demand curve**, i.e. infinite elasticity.

questions.question: In the cost‑revenue diagram (figure Econ1998_PerfComp_Cost), profit is maximized at the output level
questions.explanation: Profit maximization occurs where \(MR = MC\); this intersection corresponds to output **OL**.

questions.question: Unlike the retailer, the wholesaler provides

options.text: useful information to the manufacturer about consumers’ taste
useful information to the customers on the benefits and uses of the product
useful information about market trends and finance to the manufacturer

questions.explanation: As a link between producers and retailers, wholesalers are well placed to provide **feedback on consumer preferences** to manufacturers.

questions.question: Liquidation of a limited liability company implies that the

options.text: company may not pay its debt
debts of the company can only be paid from its own assets
debts of the company are paid from both business and private funds of the owners
debts of the company must be paid from public funds only

questions.explanation: With **limited liability**, shareholders’ personal assets are protected; company debts are settled from **company assets only**.

questions.question: One form of business organization which is not motivated solely by the profit objective is the
questions.explanation: Co‑operative societies aim at **mutual benefit of members**, not just profit maximization.

questions.question: Which of the following can have their shares quoted on the stock exchange?
questions.explanation: Only **public limited liability companies (plc)** are listed and traded on the stock exchange.

questions.question: The sector that employs the largest proportion of the active labour force in Nigeria is the
questions.explanation: **Agriculture** remains the largest employer of labour in Nigeria.

questions.question: An entirely domestic effort directed at improving agricultural production in Nigeria is the
questions.explanation: The **Agricultural Development Programme (ADP)** is a Nigerian government initiative; FAO is international.

questions.question: A factor that influences the location of a firm near its market is the

options.text: high cost of transporting finished goods

questions.explanation: If it is expensive to move finished goods, firms reduce cost by locating **close to the market**.

questions.question: In many developing countries, infrastructural problem is acute due to the shortage of

options.text: supporting services that encourage economic activities

questions.explanation: Infrastructural facilities (roads, power, communication) are **supporting services**; their shortage hampers development.

questions.question: Export‑promotion policy is primarily concerned with the

options.text: processing of raw materials to increase their value
making of international routes safe for export commodities
reduction in the number of imported items
encouragement of the production of export commodities

questions.explanation: Export promotion focuses on **stimulating the production and sale of exports**.

questions.question: The petroleum industry in Nigeria is

options.text: the sole source of the nation’s revenue
the oldest industry in the country
a factor in the decline in the nation’s foreign reserves

questions.explanation: Oil is the **mainstay** of Nigeria’s economy, contributing most export and government revenue.

questions.question: Crude petroleum is a good example of a
questions.explanation: Crude oil reserves **deplete over time**; they are a wasting asset.

questions.question: One of the techniques of monetary control used by the Central Bank of Nigeria is
questions.explanation: Selective credit control (e.g. varying credit terms by sector) is a classic **monetary‑policy tool**.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the value of money?

options.text: It varies inversely with the price level
It varies directly with the price level
It depreciates in the period of deflation
It is not affected by the price level

questions.explanation: Real value of money \(\propto 1/P\); as **price level rises, the value of money falls**.

questions.question: If the reserve requirement for commercial banking in Nigeria were 30%, a commercial bank which receives an initial cash deposit of N3,000 is in a position to lend out
questions.explanation: Required reserves = \(0.30 \times 3000 = 900\). Maximum loan = \(3000 - 900 = 2100\).

questions.question: An issue of bank‑notes not backed by gold but by government securities is known as
questions.explanation: A **fiduciary issue** is currency backed by the government’s credit/securities rather than gold.

questions.question: A rise in the market price of fixed‑interest securities is an indication that the

options.text: market rate of interest has risen
market rate of interest has fallen

questions.explanation: Bond prices move **inversely** with interest rates; higher bond prices imply **lower market interest rates**.

questions.question: An increase in government expenditure will lead to

options.text: an increase in the level of aggregate demand
an increase in total tax revenue
availability of substitutes for the commodity

questions.explanation: Government spending is a component of aggregate demand: **AD = C + I + G + (X−M)**; higher \(G\) raises AD.

questions.question: When an indirect tax is levied on the producer of a good, the burden on the consumer will depend largely on the

options.text: elasticity of demand for the good
proportion of the consumer’s income spent on the goods
elasticity of demand and supply of the commodity
availability of substitutes for the commodity

questions.explanation: Tax incidence depends on the **relative elasticities of demand and supply**.

questions.question: If a government wants to reduce the level of inflation, it will
questions.explanation: A **budget surplus** withdraws demand from the economy and helps curb inflation.

questions.question: If a country’s national income increased from N1000 billion to N1100 billion over a period of 2 years, what was the average annual rate of growth of national income over the period?
questions.explanation: Total growth = \(100/1000 = 10\%\) over 2 years; average per year = \(10\%/2 = 5\%\).

questions.question: A fall in the marginal propensity to save will lead to
questions.explanation: If \(MPS\) falls (so **\(MPC\) rises**), the multiplier \(k = 1/(1-MPC)\) increases; for given injections, **national income rises**.

questions.question: Which of the following is a transfer payment?

options.text: gift to a motherless babies’ home

questions.explanation: A **gift or donation** is a transfer payment; it is not made in return for current production.

questions.question: The major objective of economic growth is to

options.text: redistribute income and other benefits of growth
equalize opportunities for education and employment
increase the aggregate expenditure on goods and services
increase the real per capita income

questions.explanation: Economic growth is typically measured as a sustained rise in **real per capita income/output**.

questions.question: The Family Support Programme in Nigeria essentially focuses on
questions.explanation: The FSP aimed at **improving family welfare and reducing poverty**, especially among women and children.

questions.question: Economically, underdeveloped countries are characterized by

options.text: high rate of population growth and low rate of economic growth
high rate of economic growth and low rate of population growth
high rate of population growth and high rate of economic growth
low rate of population growth and low rate of economic growth

questions.explanation: Many underdeveloped countries experience **rapid population growth** but **slow economic growth**.

questions.question: One of the major consequences of urban‑biased development programmes in Nigeria is that they

options.text: transformed rural areas into urban centres
increased the level of specialized manpower in the cities

questions.explanation: Concentrating development in cities encourages **mass migration from rural to urban areas**.

questions.question: Development plans have not been successful in some developing countries largely because of

options.text: shortage of skilled labour and experts

questions.explanation: Implementation is often hampered by **shortage of skilled personnel and managerial expertise**.

questions.question: The balance of visible trade is the difference between the value of

options.text: exchange rate of local and foreign currencies

questions.explanation: Visible trade refers to **tangible goods**; balance of trade = value of exports of goods minus imports of goods.

questions.question: If a country has a balance of payments surplus on current accounts, this means that

options.text: the total invisible export is greater than invisible import
the value of goods exported must be greater than the value of goods imported
there must be a positive balance on capital account
the aggregate of the balance of trade and the invisible balance must be positive

questions.explanation: The **current account** equals balance of trade (goods) plus net invisibles; a surplus implies the **sum is positive**.

questions.question: If a country operates a freely floating exchange rate system and suffers a balance of payments deficit, the deficit can be eliminated through

options.text: a rise in the external value of its currency
a fall in the external value of its currency
an increase in the volume of imports
the consumption of more foreign goods

questions.explanation: Under floating rates, a deficit leads to **currency depreciation**, which makes exports cheaper and imports dearer, helping to correct the deficit.

questions.question: The Economic Commission for Africa was set up by the
questions.explanation: The Economic Commission for Africa is a **regional commission of the United Nations (UNO)**.
